M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 and M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20, a Probate and Family Court may modify a custody or parenting order upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and where modification is in the child’s best interests.

M.G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: Under M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 and M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20, a Probate and Family Court may modify a custody or parenting order upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and where modification is in the child’s best interests.

M.G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction to modify its prior judgment under M.G.L. c. 208, § 28, M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and the general equity powers of the Probate and Family Court pursuant to M.G.L. c. 215, § 6.

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: Because joint legal custody requires the ability of the parents to communicate and cooperate effectively on major decisions—see Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)—Defendant’s actions demonstrate a breakdown in the shared decision‑making arrangement previously ordered by this Court.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses when joint custody is appropriate and expressly states that for joint or shared custody to work, both parents must be able to agree on basic child‑rearing issues and be willing and able to cooperate in making major decisions. The court further describes joint custody as synonymous with joint decision-making and emphasizes that it is appropriate primarily for relatively stable, amicable parents. This reasoning supports the proposition that joint legal custody requires effective parental communication and cooperation on major decisions, and that a breakdown in such cooperation undermines joint custody.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “[W]e agree with the trial judge’s observation that in order for joint custody or shared responsibility to work, both parents must be able mutually ‘to agree on the basic issues in child rearing and want to cooperate in making decisions for [their] children.’ … Joint custody is synonymous with joint decision making and a common desire to promote the children’s best interests. … [I]n order to be effective ‘joint custody requires two capable parents with some degree of respect for one another’s abilities as parents, together with a willingness and ability to work together to reach results on major decisions…’”

Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that interference with or failure to cooperate regarding a child’s education or welfare can constitute such a material change.
Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).support_reasoning: The case is an alimony modification case focused on retirement and ability to pay; it does not involve child custody, parenting plans, or interference with a child’s education or welfare. The opinion nowhere discusses what constitutes a material change in circumstances for child-related issues, and thus cannot be cited as authority that interference with or failure to cooperate regarding a child’s education or welfare can be a material change. The claimed proposition is therefore not supported by this decision.
Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment.” Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368 (1981). Here, Rudolph was successful in modifying the divorce judgment with respect to his alimony obligation, but he did not succeed in terminating that obligation.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that interference with or failure to cooperate regarding a child’s education or welfare can constitute such a material change.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The case is about removal/relocation standards where parents share joint legal and physical custody, and how to apply the best-interests test under G.L. c. 208, § 30. It does not discuss modification based on a material change in circumstances, nor does it address interference with or failure to cooperate regarding a child’s education or welfare as a basis for such a material change. The quoted language about education concerns the child’s school situation for best-interests analysis, not parental interference or material-change doctrine.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “Shared legal custody carries ‘mutual responsibility and involvement by both parents in major decisions regarding the child’s welfare including matters of education, medical care and emotional, moral and religious development.’ G. L. c. 208, § 31. … Shared physical custody in particular carries with it substantial obligation for cooperation between the parents.”

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that interference with or failure to cooperate regarding a child’s education or welfare can constitute such a material change.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns Massachusetts courts treating interference with or failure to cooperate regarding a child’s education or welfare as a material change in circumstances (typically for modification). Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas is a removal and custody case establishing the ‘real advantage’ standard and defining joint legal custody in statutory terms; it does not discuss material changes in circumstances or address interference with education or welfare as a basis for modification. Therefore it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The judge did award joint or shared legal custody, which G. L. c. 208, § 31 (1984 ed.), defines as ‘a continued mutual responsibility and involvement by both parents in decisions regarding the child’s welfare in matters of education, medical care, emotional, moral and religious development.’ As we have said, he awarded physical custody, or possession of the children, to the wife.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that interference with or failure to cooperate regarding a child’s education or welfare can constitute such a material change.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion is about an initial custody determination between unmarried parents and the interaction between the best interests standard and G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a). It does not concern modification of an existing custody judgment based on a material change in circumstances, nor does it discuss parental interference with or failure to cooperate regarding a child’s education or welfare as a ground for such modification. Nothing in the holding or reasoning establishes that such interference constitutes a material change.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20….”

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that interference with or failure to cooperate regarding a child’s education or welfare can constitute such a material change.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion is a custody and domestic partnership case, not a modification case based on material change in circumstances. While it does discuss a parent’s efforts to alienate the child from the other parent and interfering with the child’s relationship as a factor in the best‑interests analysis, it does not frame this conduct as a “material change” warranting modification of an existing custody order. Thus it does not establish or affirm the specific proposition that interference with a child’s education or welfare constitutes a material change in circumstances for modification purposes.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “The judge found that disrupting the attachment a child has to a parent and behaving in ways designed to alienate a child from that parent causes harm that can be long term, and if sole physical custody must be awarded because of geographic distance between parents, ‘it is in the best interests of a child to be in the sole custody of the parent who can support the involvement of both parents rather than with the parent who alienates the child from the other parent.’”

Adoption of Don, 435 Mass. 158 (2001).proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that interference with or failure to cooperate regarding a child’s education or welfare can constitute such a material change.
Adoption of Don, 435 Mass. 158 (2001).support_reasoning: This opinion is about care and protection and termination of parental rights, focusing on abuse, neglect, service plan noncompliance, and evidentiary/due process issues. It does not discuss modification of prior custody or support orders based on a ‘material change’ standard, nor does it address interference with or failure to cooperate in a child’s education or welfare as a specific ground for such a material change. Therefore it does not provide authority for the proposition claimed.
Adoption of Don, 435 Mass. 158 (2001).relevant_excerpt: In order to grant a petition to dispense with parental consent to adoption pursuant to G. L. c. 210, § 3, due process requires that the judge must find by clear and convincing evidence, Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745, 748 (1982), based on subsidiary findings proved by at least a fair preponderance of evidence, Care & Protection of Laura, 414 Mass. 788, 793 (1993), that a parent is currently unfit to provide for the welfare and best interests of the child.

Care and Protection of Ian, 46 Mass. App.raw_text: Care and Protection of Ian, 46 Mass. App. Ct. 615 (1999)
Care and Protection of Ian, 46 Mass. App.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that interference with or failure to cooperate regarding a child’s education or welfare can constitute such a material change.
Care and Protection of Ian, 46 Mass. App.support_reasoning: The opinion in Care and Protection of Ian deals with standards for findings of parental unfitness, burden of proof, staleness of evidence, and the standard for restricting or terminating visitation. It does not address modification of custody orders based on a ‘material change in circumstances,’ nor does it discuss interference with or failure to cooperate regarding a child’s education or welfare as a basis for such a material change. Therefore, it does not support the proposition claimed.
Care and Protection of Ian, 46 Mass. App.relevant_excerpt: “The judge’s findings in a custody proceeding must be specific and detailed so as to demonstrate that close attention has been given the evidence and such findings must prove current parental unfitness clearly and convincingly.… Throughout the adjudicatory stage of a care and protection proceeding, as in an adoption proceeding, the burden of proving current parental unfitness remains squarely upon the petitioner.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that interference with or failure to cooperate regarding a child’s education or welfare can constitute such a material change.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns an initial custody determination and the need for explicit findings regarding domestic violence and its effect on the child. It does not address modification of an existing custody order, material change of circumstances, or interference with or failure to cooperate in a child’s education or welfare as a basis for such a change. Accordingly, it does not support the proposition that Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that interference with or non-cooperation about a child’s education or welfare can constitute a material change.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below “fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.” … The Probate Court failed to consider the special risks to the child in awarding custody to a father who had committed acts of violence against the mother. … Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication.
